page.title: Synopses

synopsis.code:
mal_block_synopsis = element synopsis { attribute style { xsd:NMTOKENS } ?, attribute * - (mal:* | local:*) { text } *,
mal_title ?, mal_block_desc ?, mal_block + }

page.p: The synopsis element allows you to mark up a block as providing an overview of the material being presented. It is useful for providing a listing of functions, commands, or options in reference material, or for enumerating the items in a menu or other graphical control element.

item.p: The style attribute takes a space-separated list of style hints. Processing tools should adjust their behavior according to those style hints they understand.
The synopsis element can have attributes from external namespaces. See for more information on external-namespace attributes on inline elements.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Use synopsis to create an overview of functions:

example.code: Beanstalk Functions Use these methods on a Beanstalk object. void add_bean (Bean bean); int count_beans ();

synopsis.title: Beanstalk Functions
synopsis.desc: Use these methods on a beanstalk object.

section.title: Processing Expectations
section.p: A synopsis element is rendered as a displayed block, with each of its child elements interpreted as block elements. Since a synopsis element often contains large blocks, and is generally offset from the running text, display tools may opt to render it inside a colored box, with a border, or otherwise differently from the surrounding text.
If a title element is provided, it should appear at the top of the block and be clearly marked as the title using font variations or other stylistic means.
